div.ab: zōt ud rāspīg sastica, zōt vaṇtāca... vid. Nērangs; Anklesaria, Kotwal and Boyd, Geldner.

Apparatus.Commentary: Y15.1b] cf. VrS15.1c-d (c) aməṣ̌ə̄ spəṇtə̄ vaŋhūš srīrāiš nāmąn āzbaiia (d) aməṣ̌ə̄ spəṇtə̄ vaŋhūš srīrāiš nāmąn aṣ̌ahe frāiieze. Likely error in the Yasna transmission. frāiieze needs the direct object (except if we understand them as two verbs in apposition. frāiieze alone with the following bərəja vaŋhə̄uš aṣ̌ahe... seems unlikely. bərəja vaŋhə̄uš aṣ̌ahe bərəja daēnaiiā̊ vaŋhuiiā̊ māzdaiiasnōiš is a quotation of Y35.1..

Parallels.ab: bərəja vaŋhə̄uš aṣ̌ahe bərəja daēnaiiā̊ vaŋhuiiā̊ māzdaiiasnōiš quotes Y35.1 bərəjā vaŋhə̄uš aṣ̌ahe bərəjā daēnaiiā̊ vaŋhuiiā̊ māzdaiiasnōiš = VrS65.15.

daēnaiiā̊ vaŋhuiiā̊ māzdaiiasnōiš = Y0.10, Y1.14, Y22.4, Y22.24, Y22.25, Y24.3, Y24.8, Y24.29, Y25.3, Y35.1, Y53.11 (x2), Y66.19, Y66.20, Y70.3, Y72.7, Y72.11, VrS87.11; ~ Y6.12, Y16.6 daēnąm vaŋᵛhīm māzdaiiasnīm; ~ Y9.26, Yt16.5, Yt16.8, Yt16.11, Yt16.14, Yt16.16, Yt16.18 vaŋᵛhīm daēnąm māzdaiiasnīm

Nerangs.ab: sastica. zōt ud rāspīg harw dō bē gōwišn bōy ō ī ātaxš nihādan barsom ul stānišn barsom dašn hōy paydāg bē kunišn u-š tāg ī stabrtar ud rāsttar pad datuš kunišn pad abrāyēnišn az dast ī rāst ud grih ēdōn čīyōn xūbīhā abāz kardan barsom ō māhrōy bandišn dast abar barsom nihādan ka datuš bē škīhēd ‡ka barsom drahnā bē mānēd u-š ān ī pad āsāyišn ēw tāg az kustag ī did abāz abrāyišn ast kē ān ī hōy gōwēd ka barsom drahnā bē mānēd u-š ān bē nihišn u-š did bē bandišn u-š ē tāg az kustag ī dašn abāz abrāyišn vaṇtāca. tā daēnaiiā̊ vaŋhuiiā̊ māzdaiiasnōiš skārag abāz rāst kunišn ǰiw bē baxšišn

"Both the zōt and the rāspīg have to recite sastica. (The rāspīg) should put bōy into the fire. (The zōt) has to take the barsom (from the barsomdān) and show the right and left sides. He has to make the strongest and straightest twig to the datuš while lifting it with the right hand. He should tie again the knot so as (it is done) correctly. He has to tie the barsom to the māhrōy and should put his hand on the barsom. If the datuš gets broken and it remains (from it) the length of the barsom, he has to raise one from the other side. There is one who says: “From the left”. If it remains (from it) the length of the barsom, he has to remove it, tie it again and raise (as datuš) one twig from the right side. (Then they continue with ) vaṇtāca until daēnaiiā̊ vaŋhuiiā̊ māzdaiiasnōiš. He has to turn up again the (inverted) skūrag and distribute ǰīwām (into the skūrag)."

sastica. zōt ud rāspīg harw dō bē gōwišn bōy ō ī ātaxš nihādan ud barsom ul stānišn barsom dašn hōy paydāg bē kunišn u-š tāg ī stabrtar ud rāsttar pad datuš kunišn bē abrāyēnišn az dast ī rāst ka az rāsttar ud stabrtar ēk ast ān ī rāsttar bē datuš kunišn pad māhrōy bastan dast abar barsom nihādan vaṇtāca... ... daēnaiiā̊. vaŋhuiiā̊. māzdaiiasnōiš. skūrag abāz rāst kunišn ǰīw bē baxšišn

"Both, the zōt and the rāspīg have to recite sastica. (The rāspīg) should put bōy to the fire. (The zōt) has to take the barsom (from the barsomdān) and show the right and left sides. He has to make the strongest and straightest twig to the datuš while lifting it with the right hand. If (one has to choose) one among the “straightest” and “strongest”, he has to make the straightest to the datuš. He should tie (the barsom) to the māhrōy and put his hand on the barsom (and continue with) vaṇtāca ... daēnaiiā̊ vaŋhuiiā̊ māzdaiiasnōiš. He has to turn up again the (inverted) skūrag and distribute ǰīwām (into the skūrag)."

sastica. zōt ud rāspīg harw dō bē gōwišn bōy ō ī ātaxš dahišn barsom panǰ pad dōgānag-ē az dašn ōšmurdan tāg ī rāsttar ō datuš rāst kardan ud grih ēdōn čīyōn xūbīhā abāz kardan barsom ō ī māhrōy bandišn dast abar barsom nihādan vaṇtāca

"Both, the zōt and the rāspīg have to recite sastica. (The rāspīg) has to give bōy to the fire. (The zōt) should count five pairs of (twigs of ) the barsom from the right side, make the more straight twig to datuš and tie the knot again so as (it is done) correctly. He has to tie the barsom to the māhrōy. He should put his hand on the barsom."
barsom abar gīrišn ēk-ē rāsttar ud stabrtar pad datuš kunišn bē abrāzēnišn barsom ō ī māhrōy barišn sastica. vaṇtāca ... daēnaiiā̊ vaŋhuiiā̊ māzdaiiasnōiš. skūrag abāz rāst kunišn ǰīw bē baxšišn

"He has to take the barsom, make to datuš the one (twig) that is the straightest and the strongest and he has to raise it. He has to bring the barsom to the māhrōy (and continue with) vaṇtāca ... daēnaiiā̊ vaŋhuiiā̊ māzdaiiasnōiš. He has to turn up again the (inverted) skūrag and distribute ǰīwām (into the skūrag)."

Quotations.ab: u-š pad sastica barsom and dašn paydāg be kunišnīh az-iš ēw tāg ī stabrtar ud rāsttar pad datuš bē abrāyišn ka az dō ēk-ē ān ī stabrtar; ast kē ān ī rāsttar gōwēd ka datuš bē škīhēd ka barsom drahnāy be mānēd u-š *any pad *āsāyišn ēw tāg az kušt ī dašn abāz abrāyišn ast kē ān ī hōy gōwēd ka barsom drahnāy be mānēd u-š ān be nihišn u-š ēk-ē did bē bandišn ud andar barišn u-š ēw tāg az kust ī dašn abāz abrāyišn ast kē az ān ī hōy gōwēd

And at sastica he should display some twigs at the right hand. He should take up the strongest and straightest to serve as the datuš. If (one has to choose) one (factor) out of the two, (one should take) the strongest. There is one who says: "The straightest." If the datuš breaks, if (only) the length of the barsom remains, then he should calmly take up another one from the right side. There is one (commentator) who says "from the left side". If it (only) remains the length of the barsom, he should put that one down and tie and insert another one, and he should take up a twig from the right-hand side. There is one who says: "From the left."

ab.ab: "The chief priest and the assistant priest both say sastica and the chief priest, while saying sastica, after taking the date-palm leaf on which the knot has been tied first, he fixes (it) on the right horn of the moon-shaped stand. And while saying vaṇtāca, after striking that inverted cup (which is) near the base of the moon-shaped stands, he turns (it) upright. Then the chief priest recites alone."

"Except for the first two words of st. I, when he is joined by the rāspī, the zōt recites Y.15.1 alone. Reciting "and with religious precepts" (sasticha), the zōt puts the loop of the date-palm cord over the western horn of the barsom stand furthest from him. This tends to pull the barsom bundle toward that side of the crescent-shaped stand. While saying "and with devotion" (vaṇtācha), the zōt strikes the inverted cup against the table, turns it upright and sets it down beside the barsom stand."
